actor.name: Host 1
actor.passage: Good afternoon, Buzzketeers. We’ve interrupted your normal programming to bring you some breaking news.

actor.name: Host 2
actor.passage: This had better be good. I was watching Two and A Half Men, and Charley was trying to trick a nun into dating him!

actor.name: Host 1
actor.passage: Well, the network apologizes for that, and we’ll get back to our regular schedule shortly, but…

actor.name: Host 2
actor.passage: We’d better! How is this situation going to play out? That lady isn’t dumb!

actor.name: Host 1
actor.passage: No, I’m sure she isn’t, but…

actor.name: Host 2
actor.passage: You know, sometimes I think Charley is the half man. Because he’s so immature.

actor.name: Host 1
actor.passage: Yes, you’re right. Now, the breaking news; A never before cataloged species of salamander has been discovered in Georgia!

actor.name: Host 2
actor.passage: What?! I don’t think I heard you right.

actor.name: Host 1
actor.passage: Oh, I think you did. Not only is the salamander a brand new species, scientists have classified it in an entirely new genus. You might say that means that all other salamanders are distant cousins, instead of just cousins.

actor.name: Host 2
actor.passage: “Cousins?”

actor.name: Host 1
actor.passage: As far as how closely the species are related, at least, yes.

actor.name: Host 2
actor.passage: But how is it that we’ve never noticed this salamander before? It’s my understanding that it has been 50 years since a new genus of four-legged animals was discovered in the United States.

actor.name: Host 1
actor.passage: You’re correct; it has been fifty years. But this guy could have escaped detection because he’s so small. The new species is less than two inches long.

actor.name: Host 2
actor.passage: O! M! G! That is so small! It could fit anywhere! I could put it in my mouth!

actor.name: Host 1
actor.passage: Technically, yes.

actor.name: Host 2
actor.passage: Or it could hide behind my ear! Couldn’t it hide behind my ear? Maybe it was hiding behind people’s ears all this time!

actor.name: Host 1
actor.passage: No, it lives in creeks. Not behind ears.

actor.name: Host 2
actor.passage: But it could fit there, couldn’t it? Or, like, it could fit in… is it slippery?

actor.name: Host 1
actor.passage: Yes… Wait! Don’t say it!

actor.name: Host 2
actor.passage: It could fit in a straw!

actor.name: Host 1
actor.passage: Ah. A straw. Yes, I suppose it could. Anyway, scientists are excited to study the new species.

actor.name: Host 2
actor.passage: Because it can fit into so much stuff so easily? Like Pez dispensers?

actor.name: Host 1
actor.passage: Well, yes, sort of. This salamander, now called the patch-nosed salamander…

actor.name: Host 2
actor.passage: Patch-nosed salamander! Fantastic!

actor.name: Host 1
actor.passage: This salamander, now called the patch-nosed salamander, is one of the smallest salamanders in the world. Researchers are hoping that it will yield some clues as to why miniaturization sometimes evolves in salamanders.

actor.name: Host 2
actor.passage: Probably just for convenience, don’t you think?

actor.name: Host 1
actor.passage: Look, let’s just put Two and a Half Men back on.

actor.name: Host 2
actor.passage: Charley!
